story: NewsMum cuddled five-year-old daughter for the first time in months as dad drove her body to hospital to donate her brainClare Gregory donated her little girl Olivia’s brain for tumour research after she lost her le to a tumour so rare only 40 children a year are diagnosed with itShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCarol Dyce17:49, 18 SEP 2018Updated18:27, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/little-olivias-heartbreaking-gt-after-13267480,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLittle Olivia was dressed in her pyjamas and wrapped in a blanket - her mum Clare was cuddling her and stroking her soft blonde hair while dad Tony drove them through the empty streets in the early hours. But it wasn’t an everyday family scene as  they were heading home after a late party. Heartbreakingly Clare was cradling Olivia’s leless body just hours after she died at home, weeks before her sixth birthday – nearly a year after being diagnosed with a rare, aggressive brain tumour. Each second seemed on freeze frame as they drove Olivia to a hospice to give a most precious gt – their precious daughter's brain and spine for research into the tumour that killed her – a Dfuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma .  “My heart was shattered Olivia was dead but I loved being able to cuddle her again,” said Clare Gregory from Wickford, Essex. “I hadn’t been able to do that for two months as she’d been so ill she didn't want anyone touching her. “I cradled her like a new-born baby as Tony drove with our other daughter, Eva, beside him.” At Little Havens Hospice, she gently carried Olivia into the bereavement room, with twinkling fairy lights and Disney songs softly playing in the background. “It was so peaceful and quiet,” said Clare. “We tucked Olivia up in bed and she looked like she was just asleep – our little Sleeping Beauty.” Olivia was in a special chilled bed so they were able to spend some more time with her. Then she was taken to Great Ormond Street Hospital  in London for the brain donation to its INSTINCT programme, co-funded by The Brain Tumour Charity . Now Clare wants to “shatter the taboo” of talking about donating brains for research in the hope of one day saving other families their heartache. A video of her and another parent talking about their daughters’ brain donations will be shown at The Brain Tumour Charity’s Nurses and Allied Professional Conference tomorrow .  The video aims to encourage more health professionals to make patients and parents aware that brain donation is an option. The family’s nightmare started in early 2017 when Olivia became increasingly tired. “From being a normal, lively little girl all she wanted to do was lie down,” said Clare who works for an investment bank. “She’d come home from school and flake out on the settee and, at bed time, she was out like a light.” During the May half-term, the family went on holiday to Great Yarmouth. “Instead of running around, Olivia would say ‘Daddy, you’ll have to carry me’ “She’d also been waking up on and off with headaches and nausea. “And she was always falling over.” Clare took Olivia to the GP twice and was told it was a virus and adenoid problems. “But I just knew something was dreadfully wrong,” she said. On June 1 2017, Olivia woke up in the middle of the night vomiting. Clare took her to A &amp E at their local hospital where she was again told Olivia had a virus and sent home with Calpol and Diorlyte. Two days later, Olivia kept losing her balance and was lethargic. Clare took her to a private GP and got an appointment with a consultant paediatrician the next day. Back at home, Clare found found The Brain Tumour Charity’s HeadSmart campaign, online, which raises awareness about children’s symptoms.  Ticking off Olivia’s symptoms one by one, Clare felt sick. “I said to my mother-in-law, ‘I think the consultant is going to say Olivia has a brain tumour.’” she recalls. “But when I told the consultant about my fears, she just said, ‘oh no, brain tumours are very rare.’ “I asked her why should Olivia be exempt? Why shouldn’t she have a brain tumour?” Two days later, Olivia was worse and the weight was dropping off her. “I told Tony I was going to take to her to A &amp E in the morning and that I wouldn’t leave until they gave her a scan,” said Clare. “At hospital, a nurse said she believed me when I told her I thought Olivia had a brain tumour. “She trusted my instinct and that I knew my child.” Olivia had an MRI scan and they had to wait hours for the results. “We had the long walk to the relatives’ room where doctors told us they’d found a ‘mass’ on Olivia’s brain,” said Clare. “I just replied ‘I know’ as Tony sat in shock.” The next day, Olivia had emergency surgery to put a shunt in her brain as she had hydrocephalus – fluid on the brain.  Surgeons took a biopsy which revealed she had an inoperable DIPG, which only affects around 40 children a year with a prognosis of 9-12 months. “The strange thing was that I’d never been able to imagine Olivia growing up,” said Clare. “Whether that was mother’s instinct, a premonition or coping mechanism, I don’t know. “But I just couldn’t see her in my mind as an older child.” Clare instantly accepted Olivia was going to die. “I had no choice, but what I couldn’t bear was the thought of her suffering,” she said. But it still came as a shock when doctors said that Olivia had 9-12 months to live. “I heard this gasp and realised it was me,” said Clare. During the summer holidays, Olivia had six weeks of radiotherapy and also started The Brain Tumour Charity-funded Biomede trial , the UK’s first adaptive trial for children with high-grade  brain tumours. She had few side-effects but her steroids made her put on weight and suffer mood swings. Determined to make the most of every second, the family banked happy memories, including a trip to Lapland UK, holiday in Marrakech, a simulated Tube drive, swimming with the dolphins in Dubai and EuroDisney. “We just did our best to carry on – we had Eva to think about, too,” said Clare. “Despite everything, there was still plenty of laughter – Olivia had a wicked sense of humour and loved lip-synching to her favourite group Little Mix’s songs. “And she and Eva were so funny together.”  Four months after Olivia’s diagnosis, Clare met another mum through a Facebook DIPG support group, who told her how her adult daughter had donated her brain. “It was a light bulb moment,” said Clare. “Tony and I met up with her and her husband. There was none of that head-tilted sympathy – they got it. “I was already 99.9 per cent sure I wanted to donate Olivia’s brain but meeting them confirmed my decision. “Talking to them calmed Tony’s fears about what would happen and how she would look afterwards.” Clare saw it as a way for Olivia to “leave her footstep on the world.” “I knew Olivia would never grow up or have a job, so I decided donating her brain for research would be her job,” she said. Clare got in touch with her local brain bank. “It was straight forward – I filled in some forms and put them away,” said Clare. “You didn’t have to sign them until after your child died, so you could change your mind.” They talked about it in code at home as “the gt.” By February, Olivia was weaker down her right side and had slurred speech. “It was coming up to nine months after diagnosis - it always felt like the clock ticking,” said Clare. Olivia’s MRI scan on March 22 revealed her tumour was growing again. She was now in the final stages of her le. Over the next few months, Olivia spent more and more time sleeping. “Olivia wanted to be at home with us so we set up a hospital bed in our lounge,” said Clare. “For five weeks, she couldn’t speak or swallow. It was horric.” June 5 2018 is a date which will be etched in their hearts forever. “Olivia was on morphine and I will never forget the dreadful sound of her breathing,” said Clare.  “Tony or I were always at her side and she just wanted to hold our hands all the time.” Clare rang her palliative care doctor for advice about Olivia’s pain relief. “While I was on the phone, she was holding Tony’s hand and just turned her head towards me,” said Clare. “Suddenly the awful noise stopped – she’d stopped breathing. “I kept saying ‘oh my god, oh my god, it’s over, it’s over’ down the phone. “The relief she wasn’t suffering any more was unbelievable. “She looked so peaceful.” Before they woke Eva up, the couple had time with Olivia to say their goodbyes. “We wanted – needed - that time –a bit like that precious time alone after giving birth,” said Clare. “I told Olivia, ‘I’m so sorry Mummy couldn’t fix this and save you.’” Tony’s parents who live nearby came to see Olivia and they woke Eva to tell her Olivia had died. “We all took it in turns to kiss her and say our goodbyes,” said Clare. They drove her to hospital themselves instead of ringing an ambulance as they wanted to be alone with her and had a letter saying they were taking Olivia for brain donation. After they spent some time with Olivia at the hospice, she was taken to GOSH for the brain donation. She was then taken back to the hospice in a pink coffin her big sister had chosen until her funeral a week later. “There were no scars or signs Olivia had donated her brain, except for a small mark under her hairline,” said Clare.  “She looked perfect. “I just wanted the cancer out of her – so that she was pure for her funeral and her ashes are pure.” Now Clare is sharing her story to help The Brain Tumour Charity raise awareness about how vital brain donation is for research. “We don’t call it a donation – we call it a gt – as it’s the greatest gt a parent can give,” said Clare. “Gting Olivia’s brain is a huge comfort as she is still leaving her trace on the world. “No one once asked me or even mentioned it was a possibility and I totally understand it’s not for every family, but I hope sharing my story gives more health professionals the confidence to ask the question. “It’s too late for my daughter but donating her brain for research may help other children in the future. “It gives me a glimmer of hope.” Poignantly, one of the videos Clare treasures is from Christmas when Olivia and Eva, 11, used an angel filter. Smiling into the camera, adorned with halo and wings, Olivia says, “Look, I’m a  angel because I can fly!” “Watching it is so bitter sweet - now she really is our  angel looking over us all,” said Clare. “Not a day goes by that I don’t ache for Olivia but  we help to one day save just one family our heartache it’s worth it – and I think our little angel would be proud of us.”

title: real lolita tragic girl 11
story: NewsThe real Lolita: Tragic girl, 11, was kidnapped and raped for months - and inspired Nabokov's scandalous novelVladimir Nabokov's novel about a professor who becomes obsessed with his teenage step daughter was inspired by a real le case of child abuse and abduction according to crime author Sarah WeinmanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Weinman12:30, 18 SEP 2018NewsSally Horner was abducted by a criminal posing as a father of one of her school friends "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne March afternoon in 1948, Sally Horner walked into a five-and-dime store located on one of Camden, New Jersey's busiest downtown streets. She was there on a dare: to steal a five-cent notebook, the initiation rite for joining a girls' club at her elementary school. Sally, just a month shy of her eleventh birthday, was desperate to join that clique. She was lonely, confiding her troubles in her school teacher. Her father had committed suicide when she was six. Her mother, Ella, struggled to find and keep work as a seamstress. Her older sister, Susan, was due to give birth to her first child later that summer, which would make Sally an aunt. Then a hand tugged on her arm.  A middle-aged man, positively ancient to young Sally, announced he was an FBI agent, and that Sally was under arrest. And  she didn't do as he said, she would be packed off to reform school. Sally understood how terrible a fate this would be. The man said he would let her go this time, but he could come back and find her, without any warning. Three months later, in June 1948, that man found Sally again as she walked home from school. He threatened her again, upping the ante: Sally had to tell her mother that he was the father of school friends, promising a week's worth of vacation on the Jersey Shore. Sally went home and told her mother the concocted story. Ella believed it. On June 14, Ella took Sally to the Camden bus station, kissed her goodbye, and saw her go away on a bus, sitting next to a man she'd never seen before. That man wasn't an FBI agent. Sally Horner was never under arrest. And the man, who called himself many names but was generally known as Frank La Salle, a career criminal only months removed from a prison term for the statutory rape of five girls between the ages of 12 and 14.  What was supposed to be a vacation transformed into a cross country nightmare that lasted twenty-one months. It took Sally from Camden to Atlantic City, to Baltimore, to Dallas, and then to San Jose, Calornia, where she was rescued – with the help of a concerned neighbour with secrets of her own – in March 1950. But Sally hardly had a chance to grow up, to recover fully from her rescue. Only two and a half years later, she would die in a tragic car accident at the age of 15. News of that car accident spread far and wide.  Sally's initial rescue was a national media sensation, even covered as far as Australia and New Zealand. But her death reached one vital inidual: the novelist Vladimir Nabokov. He read of it in the New York Times, copied the information down on a notecard  and, from the summer of 1952 through the end of 1953, wrote the rest of the novel that had so vexed him for the previous five years. That novel became Lolita, its account of a middle-aged man's obsessive, illicit, and illegal desire for a twelve-year-old girl still controversial more than sixty years after publication in 1955. And Sally Horner's plight, and its inspiration for Lolita, hid in plain sight, like a neon sign read to flash under the right circumstances, thanks to a parenthetical aside by the novel's unreliable narrator, Humbert Humbert, who wonders: “Had I done to Dolly, perhaps, what Frank Lasalle [sic], a fty-year-old mechanic, did to eleven-year-old Sally Horner in 1948?”  Research Several years ago, I stumbled upon what happened to Sally Horner while looking for my next crime story idea. Sally' s kidnapping, terrying odyssey, and dramatic rescue caught my attention with particular urgency. Here was a young girl, victimised over a twenty-one month odyssey from taking her from Camden, New Jersey to Atlantic City, then on to Baltimore, Dallas, and Calornia, by an opportunistic child molester named Frank La Salle. Here was a girl who figured out a way to survive away from home against her will, who acted in ways that baffled her friends and relatives at the time. Here was a girl who survived her ordeal when so many others, snatched away from their lives, do not. Then for her to die in a car accident just two and a half years after her rescue, her story then subsumed by a novel, one of the most iconic, important works of the 20th century, immortalised by that single parenthetical hardly anyone noticed. No wonder Sally Horner got under my skin in a way that few stories ever have before or since. No wonder I spent months chasing down court documents, talking to family members, visiting some of the places she had lived – and some of the places where her abductor, La Salle, took her. And even after a Canadian online magazine published my article about Sally's le and its connections to Lolita in the fall of 2014, I knew I wasn't finished with Sally. Or, more accurately, she was not finished with me. What drove me then and galls me now is that Sally’s abduction defined her entire short le. She never had a chance to grow up, pursue a career, marry, have children, grow old, be happy. She never got to build on the fierce intelligence so evident to her best friend that, nearly seven decades later, she spoke to me of Sally not as a peer, but as a mentor. After Sally died, her family rarely mentioned her or what had happened. They didn’t speak of her with awe, or pity, or scorn. She was only an absence. For decades Sally’s claim to immortality was as an incidental reference in Lolita, one of the many utterances by the predatory, middle-aged narrator, Humbert Humbert, that allows him to control the narrative, and of course, to control twelve-year-old Dolores Haze. Like Lolita, Sally Horner was no “little deadly demon among the wholesome children.” Both girls, fictional and real, were wholesome children.  Contrary to Humbert Humbert’s assertions, Sally, like Lolita, was no seductress, “unconscious herself of her fantastic power.” The fantastic power both girls possessed was the capacity to haunt. Over the four and a half years I spent working on The Real Lolita, I talked with a great many people about Lolita. For some it was their favourite novel, or one of their favourites. Others had never read the book but ventured an opinion nonetheless. Some loathed it, or the idea of it. No one was neutral. Considering the subject matter, this was not a surprise. Not a single person, when I quoted the passage about Sally Horner, remembered it. I can’t say Nabokov designed Lolita to hide Sally Horner from the reader. But given that the narrative moves so swtly, perhaps an homage to the highways Humbert and Dolores traverse over many thousands of miles in their cross-country odyssey, it’s easy to miss a lot as you go. Even casual readers of Lolita, who number in the tens of millions, plus the many more millions with some awareness of the novel, the two film versions, or its place in the culture these past six decades, should pay attention to the story of Sally Horner. Because it is the story of so many girls and women, not just in America and the UK, but everywhere.

story: NewseBay seller accidentally posts photo of 'high dose ecstasy pills' on clothing listingThe seller from Wolverhampton had listed the dark blue 'retro adidas jacket' for auction - but included a picture of something else entirelyShare&nbspByDavid KeaneHana Carter16:58, 18 SEP 2018NewsThe seller posted a photo of a hand holding the bag of pills "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn eBay seller posted a photo of a what appeared to be a bag full of ecstasy pills on a clothing listing by mistake. story: NewsWoman admits supplying 'MDMA bomb' to friend who died during final university 'blow-out'Katherine Lavin, 21, admitted supplying a controlled class A drug and possession of cannabisShare&nbspByNathan Sandhu16:19, 18 SEP 2018Updated16:30, 18 SEP 2018NewsJoana Burns, 22, died after taking MDMA on a night out in Sheffield "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe college pal who supplied ecstasy to a tragic student who died during a final university 'blow-out' was warned she faced jail today. Katherine Lavin, 21, was given the warning after admitting supplying a controlled class A drug and possession of cannabis. An inquest had previously heard how Lavin bought &pound7 bags of pure ecstasy known as MDMA for a group of friends including Joana Burns for a night out on June 6, last year. Joana had created two home-made 'MDMA bombs' by splitting the &pound7 powder into two cigarette wrappers. But the Sheffield Hallam University Maths student became unwell at around 3.30am and started fitting after complaining she was too hot.  She later died in hospital. Lavin, 21, from Stockport, Greater Manchester, pleaded guilty to supplying a controlled drug of class A on June 6, 2017, and possession of cannabis at a previous hearing. Computer science student Benjamin Williams, 25, today also pleaded guilty to supplying a controlled drug of class A. Both were bailed and will appear at Sheffield Crown Court on October 12 for sentencing. Addressing both defendants, Recorder of Sheffield judge Jeremy Richardson QC said: This matter is now ready for sentence.  Unfortunately, it's impossible for you to be sentenced today but you will be sentenced on the date in October. Please, read nothing into the fact that pre sentence reports are required and please read nothing into the fact you are being given bail. These are serious matters. All sentencing options remain open, that includes being sent to prison. At an inquest into the death of Joana in May, assistant coroner Abigail Combes recorded a conclusion of misadventure. Joana had attended Sheffield University's Student Union event night called Club Tuesdays on June 6, 2017. She had created two home-made 'MDMA bombs' by splitting the &pound7 powder into two cigarette wrappers, Sheffield Coroner's Court heard. The Sheffield Hallam mathematics student was in a group of six who had all taken the same amount - knowing what to take 'following research on the internet'. The group, which included Joana's boyfriend Lewis Birch, had been planning the night out for weeks and had all bought a &pound7 bag each of MDMA - which amounted to a quarter of a gram.  The inquest hearing was told one member of the group, Lavin, had bought the 'brown-coloured substance' for everyone in preparation for the night out on June 6, 2017.

story: NewsopinionKatie Hopkins' end was inevitable - she was just a story, not a journalistShe paid the price in the end, says Fleet Street FoxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist14:40, 17 SEP 2018Updated00:30, 18 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have long felt sorry for Katie Hopkins. She is a woman not only out of her depth, has not only floundered for more than a decade, but has no idea where she's gone wrong. It's hard to see her without thinking of a fly batting itself against a window until it expires, able to see the fresh air but unable to find it. If she reads this - which she might, because she defines herself only by what others think of her - she'll assume I'm a Left-wing liberal about to rail against her Right-wing freedom of speech. No, Katie. Someone who knows more than you is going to explain how the hatred has suffocated you. We both have epilepsy - mine very mild, hers very severe. The condition strikes in her sleep, led to her being expelled from Sandhurst, to break vertebrae and frequently dislocate her shoulders. She recently had brain surgery that ended the seizures but left her with a hole in her skull and needing to re-learn how to climb stairs. She blames the medication she has needed since young for the fact her oldest daughter is autistic and her youngest was born with a deformed hip that required many surgeries to correct. Those would be enough disability for most people to deal with. But Katie has an extra one - a mistaken belief that she's a journalist.  Let's not be precious about the Street of Shame. It is a trade, not a profession, and the only qualication necessary is a level of enthusiasm bordering on mental illness. But somewhere along the line most journalists get training. They get it from a practical degree, a vocational course, or at worst from paying attention to people who're doing it already. Katie became a journalist because first she became a media star, and she managed THAT with what she called being outspoken and everyone else called being a right cow. On The Apprentice in 2006 she hogged the camera by making amusingly-nasty remarks about maternity leave, fat people, and fellow contestants. She resigned at the end of the penultimate show citing childcare concerns, which others mocked because she had known what she was getting into. But it's perhaps worth noting both that her concerns were for two disabled daughters, and also that she was mocked mainly because she'd been so happy to mock others.  Katie sold her story for six-figure sums, had celebrity spats, and was pictured in flagrante in a field with someone else's husband. She got a regular column in her local paper the Exeter Express &amp Echo , but it ended after an online poll found 84% of the readers wanted her fired. It was a hint she did not take. She was invited onto TV as a guarantee of ratings. Three years ago Buzzfeed reported a former staffer at This Morning said she was always willing to cause controversy from the word go. Such programmes involve a chat with a producer in advance, and Katie would immediately come up with a firm line on something, and then wheeled on-air to spout it with little thought from either her or producers about where it would end. So in 2013 when she told Philip and Holly she wouldn't let her children play with someone called Tyler or Chardonnay or named after geography, it was pointed out one of her children was called India and the clip went viral.  Katie learned to make money by being rude and unapologetic, and the media learned to shore up their audience figures with a wingnut. Inevitably, she was offered a national newspaper column, a place in the Big Brother house, and more opprobrium as the hate multiplied. In 2015 she used her column to denounce migrants as cockroaches, and it quietly disappeared before she popped up at another website which racked up &pound150,000 damages plus costs for her groundless claim that a pair of Muslim brothers banned from travelling to Disneyland were linked to al Qaeda. She met holocaust deniers, tweeted about being with crew of a Save the Children ship she didn't board, and had repeated applications to join UKIP rejected. She made a habit out of getting it wrong. She moved on to LBC, left after calling for a final solution to Islamic terror, was questioned but not charged over alleged hate crimes, and more recently staged a picture with children at a school without their parents' or teachers' permission, a gross breach of journalistic ethics. She has her own website and, one hopes, has invested in some defamation legal insurance. Now she's been sued over a defamatory tweet, lost her home, and had to enter an agreement with her creditors. All of it is due to the simple fact that she attempted to be a journalist without any of the necessary skills.  If Katie had experience of working in the media before she became its favourite monster, she'd have known that what you don't say is just as important as what you do. By all means say you're snobby about the name Charmaine, but it might be an idea to know Shakespeare was happy to use it for one of his characters. If you make a habit of racking up legal bills for your employer, be careful with what you publish on social media. If you are caught lying, stop doing it. Steer clear of people with swastikas in their Twitter handles and  you don't know what defamation is, look it up. But more than anything else the lesson that Katie needed to learn was this: that becoming a hate figure is a viable but short media career. She chose a path that was an ever-decreasing spiral of bile, and it was only ever going to lead her into peril. I'm not sure she knows how she got there. She started out as entertainment, and ended up with the twin Pyrrhic victories of being praised by Donald Trump and winning an IPSO ruling against the Daily Mirror about the fact she was not detained for taking ketamine in South Africa, but for spreading racial hatred. Now she's broke and the only people still paying attention are creditors and knicker-snfing Nazis.  Katie was not a journalist but a controversialist - built and brought down by her ignorance of how journalism works. Her name is flung at others who make a much better fist of it, along with accusations they all want to be like her. Nothing could be further from the truth - journalists, above all things, want to be right. Katie was just a story, and it's a sad indictment of the media that it relied for attention on a sick woman spouting proto-fascist lies. But the principal blame is on Katie herself. She had enough clues, from as early as her first interview after leaving The Apprentice when Nick Hewer said her new brand had made you famous, but it's made you loathed. And where's it going to take you now? She never seems to have asked where it would lead. Even with training, she would never have made much of a journo. She has a thick skin and bloody-mindedness, but seems to lack empathy, accuracy, self-doubt or persuasiveness. She is a curiosity, but doesn't have any. The first rule of journalism is 'never become the story'. Not just because it's professionally embarrassing, but because all copy finishes the same way - with the word 'ends'. * Fleet Street Fox's new book, A Bluffer's Guide To Journalism, is published in March. story: NewsMan, 72, calmly buys £6 Wilko kne to stab victim in street moments after pair got into argumentRoy Lowe, 72, has been jailed for eight years for the attack in Nottingham town centreShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEd ChattertonHannah Mitchell17:57, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/pensioner-buys-kitchen-kne-wilko-13267831,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner calmly bought a 4.5-inch kne in Wilko to stab a man he had just argued with in the stomach. Roy Lowe, 72, plunged the &pound6 blade into body of his 38-year-old victim in broad daylight after purchasing it moments earlier from the homeware store. The video, released by police following the sentencing, shows Lowe stabbing the man in the middle of a crowded street.  Minutes before the attack, Lowe verbally abused a 24-year-old woman outside the Dog and Partridge pub in Nottingham before becoming involved in an altercation with the victim when he stuck up for her, Nottinghamshire Live reports.   A heated exchange took place between the two men, which can be seen in the video, before Lowe walked off, bought the kne, and stabbed his victim in the abdomen. The victim ran inside the pub followed by Lowe who was still brandishing the blade as customers watched on in horror - although he did not attack him again. Shortly afterwards he was tackled to the ground by two members of the public and pinned down until police arrived and arrested him. The victim was taken to hospital following the attack with non le-threatening injuries.  The OAP pleaded guilty to having an offensive weapon and intentionally inflicting grievous bodily harm on the 38-year-old man in Milton Street at a court hearing earlier this year. Today, he was sentenced at Nottingham Crown Court to eight years in prison. Detective Sergeant Andy Buxton, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: This was a calculated attack where Lowe has bought a kne with the sole intention of stabbing a man who he had an argument with.

title: revealed most annoying things work
story: NewsRevealed: The most annoying things about work meetings and most overused office jargon - from 'no-brainer' to 'ASAP'A study found that workers across Europe spend an awful lot of time in meetingsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAstrid HallJon Livesey15:53, 18 SEP 2018NewsOffice workers spend a lot of time in meetings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe average employee wastes nearly 13 working days every year - in ‘unproductive’ meetings, it has emerged. A European study of 2,000 employees in the UK, France and Germany found the typical staff member spends a total of 187 hours - or the equivalent of 23 days a year - in meetings. The bad news is 56 per cent of those get-togethers are generally 'unproductive' - and 66 per cent of those polled even admitted they make excuses in order to avoid meetings. The research by business travel hotel brand Crowne Plaza Hotel &amp Resorts also found one in 10 will pretend they got the time or date wrong, and one in 20 even admitted to calling in sick to get out of a meeting entirely. Mike Greenup, vice president brand management, said: “Meetings are essential for collaboration and reaching business goals, but ensuring catch-ups are effective isn’t always simple.  Experts also discovered most staff reckon 40 minutes is the ‘optimum’  for an effective meeting. Interestingly, the research found that German employees are the most likely to make excuses to duck out of meetings, with nearly three quarters confessing to doing so. By comparison, two-thirds of French employees and just more than half of UK professionals do the same. One reason employees excuse themselves from meetings may be due to the amount of catch-ups viewed as ineffective. More than one in three admit to switching off during meetings lasting too long, deeming more than half of get-togethers they attend as ‘unproductive’. Shockingly, nearly a quarter have witnessed someone else falling asleep, and a similar number have sent personal messages during a professional gathering . It also emerged employees are more likely to enjoy a meeting  it is held off-site and involves free food and drink. Over a third would get more enjoyment from a meeting with a relaxed atmosphere, and nearly two thirds would prefer for someone else to organise and run the meeting. Nearly two-thirds agreed mornings are generally better for meetings, with meetings between 9:30am and 11:30am revealed as the prime time for professional gatherings. The study showed that meeting pet peeves were also universal. Respondents said the most frustrating things about meetings, were people talking over each other, meeting rooms that are too hot or cold and people who arrive late.

title: single mum who lost hands
story: NewsSingle mum with sepsis who lost hands, feet and part of her lung now preparing to climb Mount KilimanjaroCorinne Hutton, 48, became a quadruple amputee five years ago and was given a five per cent chance of surviving the potentially fatal infectionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Ward17:25, 18 SEP 2018Updated17:38, 18 SEP 2018NewsCorinne Hutton, quadruple amputee and founder of the charity Finding Your Feet "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA determined mother who had her hands and feet amputated following le-threatening sepsis is getting ready to scale the highest mountain in Africa. Corinne Hutton, 48, became a quadruple amputee five years ago and was given a five per cent chance of surviving the potentially fatal infection. She also had part of her lung removed last year - making her more at risk of altitude sickness. But despite her disabilities, single mum Corrine is preparing to climb Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania on October 1 to raise cash for the charity she founded. The ascent is expected to take five days, and she will be joined by ten other fundraisers.  Corrine said: Initially a lot of people tried to warn me against it, saying that the risks outweigh the rewards. I've taught my son to never say 'I can't' so it wouldn't be fair  I said it. If it's down to determination and the ability to keep going, I'll get to the top. I'm overwhelmed by the messages of support, donations and sponsorship I've received since announcing the challenge.  All of the money will change the lives of amputees for the better. Hopefully others will see my efforts and want to be the best they can be. The mother, from Lochwinnoch, Renfrewshire, has been building up her strength by working out with a personal trainer, doing Pilates and swimming. In 2015 she was the first female quadruple amputee to summit Ben Nevis and recently climbed to the summit of Ben Lomond. According to the NHS, early symptoms of sepsis may include:  a high temperature  or low body temperature chills and shivering a fast heartbeat fast breathing  In some cases, symptoms of more severe sepsis or septic shock  develop soon after. These can include:  feeling dizzy or faint a change in mental state – such as confusion or disorientation diarrhoea  nausea and vomiting slurred speech severe muscle pain severe breathlessness less urine production than normal – for example, not urinating for a day cold, clammy and pale or mottled skin loss of consciousness.

story: NewsStorm Ali map and tracker: When and where dangerous storm will hit - are there warnings in YOUR area?Ali could batter some places for more than 16 hours with, with forecasters warning of flying debris, falling trees, power cuts, flooding and travel disruption from 80mph winds and heavy rainShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching13:58, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/uk-weather-forecast-after-storm-13263675,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLe-threatening Storm Ali is blowing into the UK with 80mph wind warnings as it threatens to cause property damage and disruption for millions of Britons. Amber and yellow danger to le warnings for wind have been issued for all of Northern Ireland and Scotland, and parts of northern England and Wales ahead of the first named storm of the 2018-19 season. Forecasters say heavy rain, flying debris, falling trees, power cuts, flooding and travel disruption are possible in the worst-hit areas when Ali hits on Wednesday. The major storm could batter some places for more than 16 hours. Here is the latest map and tracking details revealing when and where Ali is expected to wreak havoc.  Where will Storm Ali hit? Warnings are in place for the following areas from 6am on Wednesday: Scotland Central, Tayside and Fe: Angus, Clackmannanshire, Dundee, Falkirk, Fe, Perth and Kinross, Stirling. Grampian: Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, Moray. Highlands and Eilean Siar: Na h-Eileanan Siar, Highland. Orkney and Shetland islands South West and Lothian Borders: Dumfries and Galloway, East Lothian, Edinburgh, Midlothian Council, Scottish Borders, West Lothian. Strathclyde: Argyll and Bute, East Ayrshire, East Dunbartonshire, East Renfrewshire, Glasgow, Inverclyde, North Ayrshire, North Lanarkshire, Renfrewshire, South Ayrshire, South Lanarkshire, West Dunbartonshire.    England North East: Darlington, Durham, Gateshead, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, Northumberland,Redcar and Cleveland, South Tyneside, Stockton-on-Tees, Sunderland. North West: Cumbria, Lancashire. Yorkshire and Humber: North Yorkshire. Northern Ireland County Antrim, County Armagh, County Down, County Fermanagh, County Londonderry, County Tyrone. Wales Conwy, Denbighshire, Gwynedd, Isle of Anglesey.  When will Storm Ali hit? Torrential rain and strong winds will hit Northern Ireland and western parts of Scotland in the early hours of Wednesday. Ali will then sweep across the west of Scotland and northern parts of England and Wales through the morning. Fierce winds and heavy rain will persist through the afternoon and, in some places, into the evening. A yellow warning for wind is due to expire at 10pm on Wednesday, while the more severe amber warning is set to end at 5pm. Ali is arriving one day after the remnants of former hurricane Helene slammed some areas with 80mph winds and heavy rain. What are the biggest threats? Ali's winds will gust to 80mph and up to 70mm of rain is possible in parts of western and central Scotland. According to the Met Office, people in the warning areas should prepare themselves for:  Flying debris is likely and could lead to injuries or danger to le. Road, rail, air and ferry services may be affected, with longer journey times and cancellations possible. Some damage to buildings is possible, such as tiles blown from roofs. Falling trees or branches. Power cuts may occur, with the potential to affect other services, such as mobile phone coverage. Some roads and bridges may close.   The Met Office said in its amber warning: Storm Ali will bring a spell of very strong winds to Northern Ireland from early on Wednesday morning, before these strong winds spread to far northwest England and central and southern Scotland by late morning. Strong winds will be accompanied by heavy squally showers. Some areas, especially high ground and coastal regions, including within the Central Belt, could see gusts of 80 mph at times. Winds will ease from the west through the afternoon. Ali is the first named storm of the 2018-19 season. The Met Office and Ireland's national weather service have decided to name major storms to bring greater urgency to warnings that encourage people to take precautions. Bronagh, Callum and Deirdre are among the other names to be used this season.  Why was an amber warning issued? The Met Office uses three colours to warn of dangerous storms - yellow, amber and, for the most severe, red. An amber warning is issued when severe weather could put lives in danger and disrupt travel. The Met Office said: You should think about changing your plans and taking action to protect yourself and your property. You may want to consider the impact of the weather on your family and your community and whether there is anything you need to do ahead of the severe weather to minimise the impact.

title: burning man organisers abandon 747
story: NewsWhy 747 jumbo jet has been abandoned in the middle of the desertUS officials say the towering aircraft is trespassing on public lands and must be moved to a new locationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil Murphy11:44, 18 SEP 2018Updated11:49, 18 SEP 2018NewsThe plane was ditched 12 miles from the Burning Man site "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA jumbo jet that was abandoned at a major festival in the Nevada desert is still to be relocated - two weeks after the event ended.  The partially-assembled 747 was one of the main attractions at this year's Burning Man , an extravagant week-long party that attracts 80,000 revellers to the state's remote Black Rock desert.  Now angry officials say Burning Man volunteers are trespassing on public land after they moved the 40-foot tall aircraft to a new location without authorisation.  One of the main principles of the environmentally-conscious festival, which promotes 'decommodication' and self-reliance, is to 'leave no trace'.  It was moved off the event site without authorisation. So its legal status is in trespass with unauthorised use, Rudy Evenson of US Buerau of Land Management  told the Reno Gazette Journal .  Bottom line is, we're evaluating options for getting rid of it. Big Imagination, the collective that organises Burning Man, introduced the installation in 2015 after they gutted the defunct plane and decorated it with luminous LED lights. The group has now issued an online statement to allay concerns that future editions of the festival are under threat. Volunteers have been told by BLM that they must reapply for a permit to transport the plane after it ran out earlier this month.  In a statement on their website , Big Imagination insist that they have not abandoned the jet and say they simply want to park it at a nearby storage facility.   They said: As a collective of 500+ volunteers who have been working on this since 2014 the last thing we would want to do is to leave behind an ecological disaster on the playa or in any way impact Burning Man from getting their permit,' they said. We acknowledge that our exodus plan has not gone as expected and we apologize for any undue stress this has caused to the greater burner community, for the Burning Man Org, and especially the BLM with whom we've always sought good relations and whom we are working closely with to resolve this situation as rapidly as possible. We are working with the BLM to move the plane into its storage location in a manner that is in compliance with the requisite regulations and also in good stewardship of the land.

story: NewsWoman's perfect Tinder date with 'The One' shattered by five simple wordsThey had been messaging for a while and she thought she knew him pretty well - but she was very, very wrongShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor10:19, 18 SEP 2018Updated18:19, 18 SEP 2018News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTinder can be a tricky game, so when one woman went on the perfect date she thought that was it. title: island home 100 sets twins
story: NewsTiny island home to 100 sets of twins baffles doctors - with many siblings wearing identical clothesThere are 78 pairs of non-identical twins and 22 pairs of identical twins – including one pair of conjoined twinsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySanjay Pandey13:34, 18 SEP 2018Updated13:35, 18 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/take-tour-filipino-island-thats-13265258,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tropical island in the Philippines is home to around 100 sets of twins - a phenomenon which has baffled both doctors and scientists. According to local legend, the bizarre occurrence of twinning started on the island generations ago. Now there are 78 pairs of non-identical twins and 22 pairs of identical twins – including one pair of conjoined twins. Many of siblings continue to wear identical outfits even after they enter into adulthood, making it really impossible for outsiders to dferentiate one sibling from the other. In the Alabat island, four-month-old Gian and John are the youngest twins with the oldest twins Eudosia Meras and Antonina Meras in their 80s.  Scientists and doctors alike have been baffled as to why so many twins are born on the island. Although there is no government data on the twinning, a 2015 report conducted by the state, recorded the birth of 12 twins in the single year in the tiny island. With the rate of twins increasing, local doctors and the scientists are now busy studying the medical marvel that, they say, would prove to be beneficial for childless couples. To date, only a single village in India, are known to have the highest number of twins. The small village of Kodinhi in Kerala in southern India had reported the presence of around 300-350 twins within the boundaries of the same village. Doctors in the Philippines have ruled out the genetic reason as to why the twinning keeps happening in these pockets, they believe that the environment has more to do with it. Although some suggested that the drinking water should be studied. The 86-year-old grandmothers Eudosia and Antonina Meras are believed to be the oldest twins living in the island. Both widowed, the pair say they support one another.  Antononia who got married at an early age of 19 explains how her husband dferentiated between her and her twin sister. “In the initial days, my husband would often mistake Eudosia for myself. There have been some embarrassing incidents when my husband amorous overtures to my sister thinking that it was me. I had to then show him the mole on my nose, while my sister doesn’t have it. That solved the problem once and for all,” said Antononia. Her sister Eudosia chirpy like a teenager pitched and showed the mole on her lips: “See, I have a mole on my lower lips that why I am very talkative. ‘In our letime, we noticed that there are twins like us in the island. Pyotr, a vocal critic of Russian President Vladimr Putin, fell into a coma last week following a court hearing and was rushed to hospital. The Mediazona publisher regained consciousness last week and was then transported to Germany for treatment. Pyotr temporarily lost his sight, hearing and ability to walk, but is doing better since he arrived in Germany on Saturday.  It is highly probable that he was poisoned, Kai-Uwe Eckardt, a doctor at the Charite university hospital in Berlin, told a news conference, adding that there was no other explanation so far for Verzilov's condition. He said Verzilov was suffering from anti-cholinergic syndrome, a condition in which certain neurotransmitters get blocked. The rapid onset of symptoms - including widely dilated pupils, high blood pressure and dry mucous membranes - was strongly indicative of a poison, Eckardt said. He added: “We assume he has an intoxication lasting almost a week now. The clinical findings speak for a specic drug group, but the substance is unknown”.  Karl Max Einhaeupl, chairman of the Charite hospital, said Pyotr improves day by day and he is no longer at risk. But six days after the substance is likely to have been ingested, the chances of identying it are not high, the doctor said, adding that it could be medicine, a natural substance or plant material. Although Verzilov is no longer in danger, he still needs intensive medical care. Pyotr's ex-we Nadezhda Tolokonnikova said his family and friends think it’s too dangerous for him to  to Russia after poisoning “assassination attempt. Verzilov is publisher of Mediazona, an online news outlet that focuses on human rights violations inside Russia's penal system.

The 16-year-old girl was at a boarding school in Dehradun, India, when she was allegedly attacked by four 17-year-old boys. They are accused of luring her to a store room to help with preparations for a school event before carrying out the gang-rape. After reporting the attack to a member of staff, the girl, who has not been named for legal reasons, claimed she was persuaded to keep quiet. Additional Director General of Police Ashok Kumar told NDTV: The school management tried to suppress the case.  The girl says she reported the case to the ayah [a school nursemaid] the same day, but they tried to dissuade her to report.  After a month, the crime has come to the knowledge of police. The school’s director, principal, administration officer, his we and the hostel caretaker have all been arrested along with four accused.

story: NewsWoolly mammoths could  to roam in 'Ice Age Park' within 10 years thanks to cloning projectMammoths died out around 4,000 years ago, but scientists believe they can bring them back by cloning DNA material from remains of the giants found in permafrostShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySteve White16:48, 18 SEP 2018Updated16:52, 18 SEP 2018NewsScientists plan to use DNA material from remains of mammoths found in permafrost to clone the giants "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScientists are hoping to clone woolly mammoths that will roam freely in a Siberian ice age park within 10 years. They will use DNA material from remains of the giants found in permafrost. And elephants could act as surrogate mums to carry the baby mammoths. The regional government in far eastern Yakutia has given experts the go-ahead to try to clone the beasts for the Jurassic Park-style reserve. Researchers are working with Russian, South Korean and &shyJapanese scientists.  Acting head of the &shyterritory Aisen Nikolaev said: “In my opinion, cloning a mammoth will happen in the next decade. “Technology is developing at an explosive pace, and what yesterday seemed to be scientic nonsense, today is an absolutely clear prospect for scientists.”  Mr Nikolaev first proposed an Ice Age Park with mammoths in 2014.

title: dundee house prices rise more than any other scottish city
story: House prices in Dundee are rising faster than in any other Scottish city, a new report has revealed. 100vw, 3000px" /Research from estate agent Aberdein Considine shows that the average home in the city was sold for more than £140,000 during the second quarter of 2018.This marks a 5.7% rise from the same period in 2017.Increases of 5.5% were recorded in Glasgow, Edinburgh, Perth and Stirling with Aberdeen showing a 1.2% drop.Dundee’s price inflation was recorded in April, May and June in the run-up to the completion of the V&ampA. Alan Cumming, national estate agency director at Aberdein Considine, said this was the first clear sign of the museum having an impact on the city’s property market.He said: “Dundee has been undergoing a renaissance as this magnicent new landmark takes shape on the banks of the Tay.“The city has a growing UK and global profile and with more than 500,000 people expected to visit over the next year, this is only going to grow.“Dundee is one of the most affordable cities in the UK for first-time buyers, which makes it a popular choice for young house-hunters.“We may well be at the beginning of a period of sustained price growth and I am incredibly optimistic about what the future holds for the city’s property market.”Across Scotland as a whole, prices have soared to a record high of £169,450 after a summer market heatwave inflated prices in 27 out of the country’s 32 local authority areas.But more than three-quarters of the people surveyed by Scotland’s Property Monitor indicated that they had no intention of buying a new home, up from 43% in the first quarter.Back in July, the Tele revealed how house prices in Dundee had increased by 1.5% in May, which contributed to a 5.4% rise over the last 12 months.During that time, the average property in the area sold for £121,580 – signicantly lower than the UK average of £226,351.Buyers who made their first step on to the property ladder in the City of Discovery in May spent an average of £104,591.In September last year, it was reported by Aberdein Considine that property prices in Dundee were rising twice as fast as the Scottish average.

title: dundee united gaffer csaba laszlo blasts referee after spot kick call
story: Dundee United manager Csaba Laszlo has hit out at referee Colin Steven after he gave a controversial penalty against his side on Saturday.Steven pointed to the spot on 11 minutes when debutant Rachid Bouhenna was adjudged to have fouled Morton defender Gregor Buchanan in the box from a corner.Michael Tidser stepped up to give the ’Ton the lead in a Championship game which finished 1-1 thanks to substitute Fraser Fyvie’s last-minute equaliser.Although Csaba was pleased with the fight they showed to win a point, he was frustrated at the referee’s performance.“I am really proud of the boys because it was a really dficult game,” he said.“You get a penalty against you, and I don’t want to talk about the performance of the referee because it’s not my job, but I thought it was a foul for us at first.“I didn’t hear the whistle, then the referee shows for the penalty but I think, to be honest,  he gives this penalty then he has the chance to give 10 others for both sides.“It’s just my opinion and it is not all about the penalty. I don’t want to criticise the referee but, according to me, it was a very soft penalty.“I asked my players  there was contact there but they didn’t think it was one which you have to give.”Of United’s display, Csaba added: “I think for 90 minutes plus added time we played one-way football.“The boys tried hard and it’s not easy when the clock is ticking down and you still can’t score.“In the first-half we had two very good chances where we should score and in the second half we were pressing Morton.“They were, more or less, 11 behind the ball playing very deep and they tried to counter attack.“Sometimes you have these games where you have to suffer but we have to be more clinical, must be more clinical.“We can talk about the many mistakes but we have to play faster, more with the ball into feet and up front but I think on Saturday everybody showed spirit.”

title: dundee united new boy booth says he shouldnt have tried to run off injury
story: Callum Booth admits had he been a Dundee United veteran instead of a rookie, two months into the season Arabs would have seen a lot more of him than they have.The 27-year-old is ready for today’s Championship clash with Morton at Tannadice and,  he completes the 90 minutes, it will be the first time since his debut in mid-July.That’s when he damaged ankle ligaments in the Betfred Cup defeat at Ross County, an injury suffered early on in the tie.It could have forced him off immediately but the fact he played on was, he admits, a mistake on his part that was caused by him being new to the team.“Firstly, it’s been good to be back, obviously being out for five weeks was a long time,” said the former Partick Thistle defender.“It felt like ages, especially when you join a new club because you just want to make good impressions and get games under your belt right away.“It was my ankle, I did in it in the first half at Ross County and quite stupidly played on.“The physio came on, had a look and I thought I could probably run it off. I did feel it for the rest of the game but being at a new club you just want to show up well in your first game.“If I’d been here a couple of years I would have come off but, because it was my first game, I stayed on and probably made it worse – I woke up the next day and it was agony.“The result was five weeks out and that wasn’t ideal but it’s in the past now and I’m raring to go.”What he isn’t doing is expecting to walk right back into the team and he knows, in the shape of fellow left-back Jamie Robson, he’s facing strong competition for that defensive berth.“Jamie has been doing really well, he’s a good player and it’s good to have competition. There are a few boys still out and they’re coming back, so there’s going to be even more and that can only be good for the squad.“I feel that, when we have everyone fit, we have a very strong squad and it’s just going to be a case of getting everyone fit and keeping it that way. There are always injuries, though, it’s part and parcel of football.”His mission now is to help however he can as United look to keep picking up points to mount a strong promotion challenge.The aim today is to pick up three points. He knows that will not be easy against a Morton side who will be something of an unknown quantity after their recent change of manager.It saw ex-United boss Ray McKinnon quit after just three months in chare to take over at Falkirk and former Rangers star Jonatan Johansson replace him.“Any team that gets a new manager, they usually take a couple of weeks to implement what the new man is trying to do. This is Johansson’s first game in charge so we are not really too sure how they’ll set up.“One thing we know is they have good inidual players and experience in there as well in the middle of the park.“It’s going to be a tough game and they are a good side. They’ve had a good couple of seasons where they’ve always been in or close to the play-offs and done well in a few cups.”For United the aim is to build on a three-game unbeaten run that’s seen seven points taken from the last nine, though Booth believes it should have been a full house.“We are going not too bad but,  we want to be winning the league, we have to be holding on to results like the one we should have had at Alloa last time out.“We didn’t play great but 1-0 going into the last 10 minutes, we should have seen the game out. Still, seven points from the last nine after a tricky start to the season is not too bad.”

title: today you can help set a world record with the beano at dundee waterfront
story: Members of the public are being invited to take part in a world record attempt – while celebrating the opening of V&ampA Dundee.The Beano will have its very own “den” at Slessor Gardens today as part of 3D Festival.A host of local music acts are set to perform at the event, but there will also be a range of activities on offer for families and children.And the iconic comic is leading the way with its official Guinness World Record attempt to create the largest “finish the comic strip” competition ever.A special edition of The Beano has been created to mark the occasion.In it, Dennis and friends meet cartoon versions of Philip Long, director of V&ampA Dundee, and Kengo Kuma, the Japanese architect who designed the building.There are nods to Dundee’s sporting heritage – as the V&ampA is coloured tangerine and black, and blue and white, by the mischievous characters, in reference to the colours worn by Dundee United and Dundee.A version of Dennis from the 1950s, The McManus and the Star Wars-themed video of the V&ampA which came out last year, also all feature.The final cell of the comic strip is left blank and children can draw an item that they want to feature in the V&ampA.All the pictures will be collected as part of the world record bid.Mr Long will then choose a winner, which will go on display in the V&ampA.

title: va dundee all you need to know about todays 3d festival as local acts take centre stage
story: A series of Dundee musicians will herald the opening of the V&ampA today.The museum finally opens its doors to the public, with lucky ticket-holders given their first glimpse of the £80 million attraction. Across the road, in Slessor Gardens, celebrations to mark the opening continue with the second day of the 3D Festival.The event will feature a host of on-stage performances and a number of family activities.Things kick off at 11am as musician SHHE – otherwise known as Su Shaw or Panda Su – takes to the stage.She said: “Dundee is special – it doesn’t show off in ways that other cities do – so maybe in the past you had to work harder to find that out.“I’m excited to be joining some incredible local artists on-stage to celebrate its opening.”Keeping the music going from 11.50am will be Kashmir Crows, a six-piece based in the city.The group – who have been likened to bands such as Arcade Fire and Black Keys – play a mix of alternative rock, indie, soul, blues and funk, and are a familiar act on the local music scene.Lead singer Ian Black, from Lochee, said: “We pride ourselves on being a Dundonian band and to be a part of the biggest cultural event in Dundee for generations, we’re totally over the moon. We’ve been rehearsing and have just played at the Glenfiddich Festival Experiment so we’re on a roll. We can’t wait to play for everyone.”Dundee two-piece St Martiins are next up, performing a set at 12.40pm. Featuring Katie Lynch and Mark Johnston, they claim to have crafted a “unique sound” through music “laced with dark tones”.Katie said: “The V&ampA is bringing something new to the creative scene here in Dundee, which has been needing a good refresh. We’re extremely lucky as a band and I want to see more people get the chance to get involved in the music business. Today’s going to be great – we’re so happy that we were asked.”At 1.30pm is Andrew Wasylyk, the alias of Dundee writer and producer Andrew Mitchell.He describes his work as being “cinematic nostalgia” with “elements of Baroque pop and the influence of classic 1970s songwriters”. Andrew said: “It’s a privilege to be involved and to play a small part in the opening of this new chapter for the city. I’m a fan of Kengo Kuma’s architecture and I’m excited to see the V&ampA evolve and grow with the local communities. I’m really looking forward to performing with a nine-piece ensemble.”Kyle Falconer  – frontman of The View – is the most familiar name on the bill and he will appear on-stage at 2.30pm. The Dryburgh lad has been on tour promoting his debut solo album No Thank You of late, and is expected to perform hits from that LP along with a few well-known tunes from the band that made him famous.Another familiar face appears at 3.30pm in Be Charlotte  – the stage name of local singer Charlotte Brimner.She continues to make a name for herself, having signed a record deal earlier this year and performed last night before Primal Scream on the first day of the 3D Festival.Rounding the day off will be Danny Wilson icon Gary Clark, who’ll play a solo set to his hometown from 4.30pm before being joined by Sistema – the children’s schools orchestra – at 4.50pm to bring the festival to a close. Gary found fame with hits like Mary’s Prayer – which is expected to get an outing today.Organisers say the festival is all-standing and entry is via two gates on Thomson Avenue.Those attending aren’t allowed to take food or drink but outlets will be available.There will be a host of other activities taking place at Slessor Gardens, including a special event involving The Beano – where children can complete a comic cell in an attempt to break a world record.

title: va dundee huge queue as museum opens to wider public after debut weekend
story: A large queue of eager visitors has formed as people aim to get their first glimpse of the V&ampA Dundee.After a weekend of celebrations and exclusive access to lucky ballot winners, the museum opened its doors to the general public.The iconic building officially opened at 10am today.&mdash Mary&#39sChapelProject  September 17, 2018Shortly after the opening time, a large queue had formed &#8211 stretching past the RRS Discovery.The iconic £80 million museum welcomed thousands of visitors over Saturday and Sunday. Among those were city celebrities Brian Cox and Lorraine Kelly.It features a number of free exhibits as well as the featured Ocean Liners: Speed and Style, which requires the purchase of a ticket..Mr Cox said: “I think we all agree, those of us who are close to the city and who are close to what is going on here, it’s a very emotional experience.Great to see people wandering around outside the museum already 🤗We open at 10.00 everyone&#39s welcome. Let&#39s do this. pic.twitter/qegZnWzJdq&mdash V&ampA Dundee  September 17, 2018“Especially for me, I’ve known the city for many years, I was born here, went to school here and had my first theatre roles here, so to  and see what’s happening now – it’s transformed the city.“It will attract industry and it will attract tourists, it’s the beginning of hopefully a paradigm sht in Dundee and it will put Dundee on the map for the first time.“It’s an amazing experience. Where it’s situated on the Tay and what Kengo Kuma has done in terms of design – I believe he has said it is his best work.”Mr Cox said he believed Dundee will come to be defined by the museum and having been involved with the project from an early stage, he promised to attend the opening.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon also attended and even paid a brief visit to the 3D Festival over the road on Friday night appearing for selfies.
